para.caption: What is CVS?
para.text: CVS stands for "Concurrent Versions System". Many open source projects use CVS to share their code among various developers.

para.caption: How do I write log messages?
para.text:
CVS log messages really make the whole thing comprehensible and traceable. Log messages just saying "Changes" or "Correct Sth." should be heavily avoided, just like a huge commit of many changes in many files. Instead you should clearly document what you changed and why. This requires discipline - to the benefit that anyone can understand what you did. That is better for everyone.
The following format has been found readable:
|---------------------------- |revision 1.9 |date: 2002/02/26 18:09:48; author: friebe; state: Exp; lines: +22 -25 |- Makefile unified |- :ext:... added |----------------------------
For every change a - is written on the beginning of the line. Further examples:
|---------------------------- |revision 1.8 |date: 2002/02/21 14:05:02; author: friebe; state: Exp; lines: +2 -2 |- Add an optional argument "filename" |----------------------------
|---------------------------- |revision 1.3 |date: 2002/02/21 13:28:46; author: friebe; state: Exp; lines: +10 -9 |- Convert to CVS install | We have a cvs checkout on that machine, so we could directly work on | it and commit there in case of emergency. |----------------------------

para.caption: Comments in CVS log messages
para.text:
When commiting, one somebody feels the desire to add some more information to the log message, such as reasoning for the commit or further references (such as howtos, documentation, bug links) which actually have nothing to do with the changes themselves.
Use a # to prefix these "comments". |---------------------------- |revision 1.32 |date: 2004/02/16 21:51:42; author: friebe; state: Exp; lines: +120 -32 |- Fix serializing of SOAP structs for Axis |# See http://ws.apache.org/axis/ for details on their serializer |----------------------------

para.caption: Quality assurance work
para.text:
From time to time, classes undergo a quality assurance phase. That means they are checked for possible error conditions, coding standards or whether their api documentation still conforms to the current behaviour.
Commits serving these purposes will be prefixed with QA. Example: |---------------------------- |revision 1.42 |date: 2004/02/16 21:59:14; author: friebe; state: Exp; lines: +1 -1 |- QA: Whitespace fix |----------------------------

para.caption: Abbreviations used in CVS commit messages
para.text:
The following abbreviations (all in capital letters) are used in log messages:
MFH: Merge from Head (when working with branches)
MFP: Merge from Public (when working with separate CVS repositories)
WS: Whitespace
CS: Coding standards
TBD: To be discussed
TODO: (self-explanatory)

para.caption: What's the thing with those STABLE - tags?
para.text:
Setting a STABLE-tag defines that this piece can be used in a production environment. This is the commitment of the respective author that he has tested this version to a satisfying degree. With cvs status -v you can show all tags of a file:
[...] | Existing Tags: | STABLE (revision: 1.12) | Initial (revision: 1.1.1.1) | Start (branch: 1.1.1)
Other tags frequently used are NEEDS_WORK and EXPERIMENTAL.
